Nevertheless, labor supply in the hospitality, agriculture, construction, and manufacturing sectors was reportedly strained in several Districts due to recent changes to immigration policies. Wages grew across all reporting Districts, generally at a modest to moderate pace, and labor cost pressures intensified in recent weeks due to outsized increases in employer-sponsored health insurance expenses.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: National Summary > Labor Markets

retrieved_chunks.body: Labor supply continued to exceed labor demand. Contacts reported that it has been consistently easier to find workers, continuing a trend that has been in place all year. Attrition remained exceptionally low, creating less need to hire for replacement. Labor demand varied by industry, with solid demand for workers in finance and accounting alongside still-soft demand for tech workers. Several businesses in construction and leisure and hospitality reported some difficulty finding workers due to shifts in immigration policy. A large retailer reported that instead of making workforce adjustments through hiring and firing, they were repositioning longer-tenured workers to increase productivity. While some firms were strategically downsizing, there remained no signs of major layoffs.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Labor Markets

retrieved_chunks.body: Conditions in agriculture and resource-related sectors weakened slightly, as in the prior reporting period. Demand from abroad, particularly from China, reportedly continued to fall because of trade policy adjustments and negotiations. Favorable weather kept yields stable, but a recent heat wave and smoke from fires in the Pacific Northwest lowered fruit quality. Costs for packaging materials rose, and financing costs remained high. Higher costs combined with low prices for agricultural commodities continued to put financial strain on producers. Several contacts reported difficulties finding enough labor due to changes in immigration policy and resulting labor shortfalls reduced harvests. One contact emphasized that anticipated declines in sales volume would limit investment for the following season.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Agriculture and Resource-Related Industries

retrieved_chunks.body: Employment was down slightly since the last report. Surveys found softening labor demand among District employers, as well as declining head count, though seasonality played a role. A staffing firm with multiple offices saw hiring decline at the end of summer after an earlier uptick. A staffing contact in Michigan's Upper Peninsula noted healthy labor demand in manufacturing, construction, and mining, but acknowledged that "the uncertainty in the market has spurred more temp and temp-to-hire work in our area," rather than direct hiring. Hospitality and tourism firms reported that they were predominantly hiring to replace turnover; only one in ten were hiring new full-time employees, and a comparable share was cutting workers. However, recent unemployment claims across the District remained low overall. Montana employers reported healthy labor demand, but a contact said that "most hiring is to replace vacancies rather than support business expansion." Artificial intelligence was expected to have a slight dampening effect on future labor demand. A Minnesota advertising firm said there "will be a smaller need for entry-level folks" because Al tools "get this work done faster."
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis > Labor Markets

retrieved_chunks.body: Conditions in community support organizations and small businesses weakened moderately. Demand for assistance rose, particularly for food, other basic household necessities, and health care. At the same time, funding and grant cuts limited their ability to provide assistance. Small business owners reported lower demand and strained finances, as they drew down savings and reduced investment. Contacts attributed some of the decline in demand to changes in customers' behavior in response to immigration policy. Reports indicated more business closures and cuts to operating hours as well as some increases in loan delinquencies.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Community Conditions

retrieved_chunks.body: Employment in the Fifth District, on balance, was unchanged in the most recent period. A few firms grew their total head count through acquisitions and expansions into new locations. Several other firms, on the other hand, reported reducing their head count to right-size labor with slowing demand. A couple of firms expected cuts to come. For example, a South Carolina home builder reported a decline in demand due to increased prices, which they said would result in imminent layoffs. Additionally, a small jewelry store is contemplating closing due to economic uncertainty and declining demand. Labor availability continued to be a significant challenge for skilled trades. In response, a concrete manufacturer launched their first social media recruitment campaign, hoping to attract a larger pool of applicants. Wage growth remained moderate.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond > Labor Markets

retrieved_chunks.body: Employment has remained unchanged since our previous report. Most contacts reported no change to employment levels; they are not hiring, but also not laying off workers. A manufacturer in Louisville reported no change in employment levels since July and is currently postponing the filling of roles until the first quarter of 2026. Contacts in manufacturing, construction, and agriculture continue to report labor shortages due to workers not reporting to work because of fears of deportation. For example, a construction firm in Memphis reported that the reduced labor pool was driving up labor costs and resulting in project delays.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Labor Markets

retrieved_chunks.body: Employment levels were little changed on net over the reporting period. Most employers hired only to replace workers, holding head counts steady. Several contacts in manufacturing and health care noted reductions in staff levels through attrition, layoffs, and early retirements. In some cases, employment reductions were coupled with investment in artificial intelligence (AI), particularly for positions and tasks usually reserved for less experienced employees. In contrast, employers in financial services and insurance continued to hire. The number of applicants for each open position increased, and employers generally found it easier to hire. However, a few contacts in construction and manufacturing noted more difficulty finding workers for their entry-level positions, and they attributed that to reduced immigration. Turnover continued to slow across industries, and some contacts highlighted efforts to prioritize the retention of experienced employees.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Labor Markets

retrieved_chunks.body: Employment was flat over the reporting period, though contacts expected a slight pickup over the next 12 months. Reports on labor market conditions continued to be mixed. Job turnover was low, and contacts across many industries observed softening labor market conditions. An employment placement agency reported a continued decline in demand from manufacturers, and one contact in state government observed that previously announced layoffs in agricultural machinery manufacturing had been completed. A retail industry analyst expected that hiring for the holiday season would be weaker than last year. A few contacts in manufacturing and construction said they were looking to hire new workers. One noted that fear of immigration enforcement was reducing labor availability. Another contact said that revoked visas for workers at a local factory created the need to rehire for those positions. Wages and benefits costs were up modestly overall, and many contacts cited increases in health insurance premiums.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago > Labor Markets

retrieved_chunks.body: Economic activity and employment levels have remained unchanged since our previous report. Contacts continue to report that immigration policies have been resulting in labor shortages. Prices have increased moderately, with contacts reporting that inflation is eroding consumer purchasing power. Banking activity has remained unchanged since our previous report, with overall credit conditions remaining strong. Agriculture conditions are strained and have further deteriorated. The outlook remains slightly pessimistic.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Summary of Economic Activity

retrieved_chunks.body: Economic activity and employment levels have remained unchanged since our previous report. Contacts continue to report that immigration policies have been resulting in labor shortages. Prices have increased moderately, with contacts reporting that inflation is eroding consumer purchasing power. Banking activity has remained unchanged since our previous report, with overall credit conditions remaining strong. Agriculture conditions are strained and have further deteriorated. The outlook remains slightly pessimistic.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: National Summary > Highlights by Federal Reserve District > St. Louis

retrieved_chunks.body: Employment was flat overall, as both hiring and layoffs increased modestly. Manufacturing employment was unchanged on balance, as some firms added workers to meet demand, some kept head counts steady because of uncertainty, and one shed workers to offset tariff-related cost increases. Cuts to federal grant funding contributed to layoffs in the education and health-care sectors. Employment in IT services increased modestly, with hiring in sales and technical positions. Retail and tourism employment was unchanged, as contacts noted modest improvements in worker availability but worried about next summer's labor supply given expected reductions in seasonal visas. Contacts in Maine and Vermont said labor market slack in those states increased, even though certain hiring challenges persisted. Wages rose at a modest pace on average, and some contacts described wage pressures as more muted compared with a year earlier. Manufacturing wages were mixed, but up modestly on average. Salaries at IT firms were unchanged, with moderate annual increases expected at the turn of the year. With isolated exceptions, hiring plans remained limited, owing to rising cost pressures and elevated uncertainty. No major layoffs were expected in the near term, but the longer-term outlook was less secure.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston > Labor Markets

retrieved_chunks.body: Overall, contact reports suggested a slight increase in employment levels in recent weeks. Many contacts across industries said that they were hiring for open positions and normal turnover. Other contacts were hiring for current or anticipated growth. For instance, one banker reported hiring loan originators in anticipation of lower mortgage rates increasing demand. Overall, retailers held staffing levels steady in recent weeks. As one restaurateur stated, "no growth so no new positions will be added." Across industries, many contacts said that declining business activity led to reduced labor demand, and in some cases, to layoffs. One manufacturer said that they had postponed layoffs while waiting for industrial production to recover but could not delay cuts any longer.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland > Labor Markets

results.question: How did firms in different sectors respond to tariff-induced cost increases in terms of their pricing strategies?
results.expected_answer: Responses to tariff-induced costs varied by sector: In manufacturing and retail trades, some firms fully passed higher import costs along to customers. Other firms facing tariff-induced cost pressures kept selling prices largely unchanged to preserve market share and due to pushback from price-sensitive clients. In Chicago, a retail industry analyst expected peak tariff impact in the first half of 2026.
results.system_answer:
Firms responded in varied ways, and the strategies differed by sector and even within sectors:

- **Manufacturing**
  - Many manufacturers raised prices to cover higher input costs, sometimes adding explicit **tariff surcharges** (Cleveland [9]).
  - Some manufacturers **held prices steady** despite higher costs to **preserve or gain market share** (Cleveland [9], National [4]).
  - An upstate specialty appliance manufacturer raised prices twice in a year due to tariffs (New York [1]).
  - Some producers (e.g., steel producers) kept prices **unchanged** to preserve margins even as demand slowed (Atlanta [2]).
  - Several manufacturers planned **future price increases** as pre-tariff inventories were depleted (Richmond [5], Philadelphia [10], Minneapolis [15]).

- **Retail**
  - One large retailer adjusted price increases according to **demand elasticity item-by-item**, and sought alternative inputs to limit pass-through (New York [1]).
  - Nationally, some retail and manufacturing firms **fully passed higher import costs** to customers (National [4]).
  - Many retailers tried to **hold off passing through** tariff costs “as long as possible,” but **smaller retailers** had already raised prices (Chicago [8]).
  - Retailers also used **selective price increases and discounts**—raising prices on some goods while discounting others to sustain demand (Cleveland [9], Philadelphia [14]).

- **Auto sector**
  - Some auto manufacturers **absorbed** tariff-induced cost increases on new cars to avoid further demand declines (Atlanta [2]).
  - Elsewhere, auto sellers increased **incentives** to sustain demand rather than raising sticker prices (Philadelphia [14]).

- **Restaurants and Food-related businesses**
  - Some restaurants **did not significantly raise menu prices**, accepting margin compression (Boston [13]).
  - Others, facing pushback, altered offerings instead of prices: **reduced portion sizes or changed recipes** when customers resisted higher menu prices (San Francisco [6]).
  - Upstate brewing and food-related firms passed higher ingredient and packaging costs directly to consumers (New York [1]).

- **Services (professional, insurance, etc.)**
  - Some service firms reported the ability to **raise prices without much pushback** (Atlanta [2]).
  - Others, facing higher costs, increased prices in line with competitors’ moves (St. Louis [12]).
  - Insurance and related services also saw higher prices but encountered **customer resistance**, leading customers to bundle or adjust coverage to limit cost (San Francisco [6]).

- **Foreign producers’ response affecting U.S. prices**
  - In some cases, **foreign manufacturers absorbed tariff costs** to maintain market share, limiting the need for U.S. price increases (New York [1], Cleveland [7]).

Overall, tariff-induced cost increases led to a spectrum of pricing responses: full pass-through (especially in some manufacturing and retail segments), partial pass-through with selective increases, price freezes with margin compression, non-price adjustments (portion sizes, product changes), explicit surcharges, and, in some foreign-supplier cases, absorption of tariff costs to keep U.S. prices lower.
results.judge_reasoning:
Key facts in expected answer:
1) Responses varied by sector.
2) In manufacturing and retail, some firms fully passed higher import costs on to customers.
3) Other firms, despite tariff-induced cost pressures, kept selling prices largely unchanged to preserve market share and because of pushback from price‑sensitive clients.
4) In Chicago, a retail industry analyst expected the peak tariff impact in the first half of 2026.

Check against system answer:
1) Variation by sector: The system explicitly says responses “varied by sector and even within sectors” and then details several sectors. This matches.
2) Full pass‑through in manufacturing/retail: The system states "Nationally, some retail and manufacturing firms fully passed higher import costs to customers" and describes manufacturers raising prices or adding tariff surcharges. This matches.
3) Holding prices steady to preserve market share / price-sensitive clients: The system says some manufacturers "held prices steady despite higher costs to preserve or gain market share" and describes pushback or resistance in several sectors (restaurants, insurance). This matches the mechanism, including market-share and client pushback motives.
4) Chicago-specific expectation of peak tariff impact in first half of 2026: The system answer does mention Chicago in the retail bullet (“Many retailers tried to hold off passing through tariff costs ‘as long as possible,’ but smaller retailers had already raised prices (Chicago [8])”), but it does NOT mention any retail industry analyst’s expectation that the peak tariff impact would occur in the first half of 2026. This key temporal/forecast detail is missing, not contradicted.

There are no direct contradictions with the expected answer; the system answer is longer and more detailed, but omits the specific Chicago 2026 peak-impact point. Therefore it is accurate but incomplete relative to the expected answer’s key facts.

retrieved_chunks.body: The pace of price increases was mostly unchanged; selling prices continued to rise moderately while input prices again rose strongly. Many businesses continued to strategize around how to structure prices in consideration of new tariffs. One major retailer reported adjusting price increases based on the demand elasticity for each item, and many reported working with vendors to find alternative inputs to mitigate the impact of tariffs on their costs. A Long Island area importer and wholesaler of auto parts noted that tariffs on goods imported from India presented particularly steep challenges to their business, while a coffee roaster and supplier noted that tariffs on imports from Brazil threatened their ability to remain profitable. A specialty appliance manufacturer from upstate New York hiked their prices for the second time this year to account for the impact of tariffs on their costs. An upstate brewing company reported that elevated ingredient and packaging material costs were getting passed along to the consumer. A pharmaceutical company reported that foreign manufacturers were absorbing tariff costs to maintain market share and production levels. Some restaurants noted escalating costs for food—particularly beef—and imported wine were hurting their businesses. A New York City-based specialty contractor reported that congestion pricing was pushing up the cost of doing business considerably. Looking ahead, firms expect significant pricing pressures to persist.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Prices rose moderately. Firms noted a wide range of tariff impacts on operating costs and pricing responses, as well as approaches to managing those impacts, such as absorbing cost increases, negotiating with suppliers, and passing through to customers. Contacts warned that price pass-through resulting from tariffs has just begun and expect to see prices rise into 2026. Some auto manufacturers reported feeling the pinch from tariffs on new car sales but were absorbing these increases to prevent further declines in demand. Some firms, however, reported little to no tariff impacts thus far. A few service-oriented firms noted an ability to increase prices without pushback from customers. Steel prices flattened amid slower demand, but some producers held prices steady to preserve strong margins. Internal cost pressures continued to mount, and firms noted there was little room to cut costs further. The accelerated depreciation schedule from the One Big Beautiful Bill Act will help to offset cost pressures going forward according to several contacts.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Selling prices increased slightly overall, while rising more sharply in the manufacturing sector due to the widespread impact of tariffs. A computer manufacturer reported that U.S. customs was applying steel and aluminum tariffs to products that do not contain these metals and that challenges to these tariffs were taking time to resolve. A professional and business services firm reported that health-care and business insurance premiums were rising faster than revenues. Service firms expect selling price increases to accelerate over the next 12 months, while manufacturing executives expect price growth to remain steady.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Prices rose further during the reporting period. Several District reports indicated that input costs increased at a faster pace due to higher import costs and the higher cost of services such as insurance, health care, and technology solutions. Tariff-induced input cost increases were reported across many Districts, but the extent of those higher costs passing through to final prices varied. Some firms facing tariff-induced cost pressures kept their selling prices largely unchanged to preserve market share and in response to pushback from price-sensitive clients. However, there were also reports of firms in manufacturing and retail trades fully passing higher import costs along to their customers. Waning demand in some markets reportedly pushed prices down for some materials, such as steel in the Sixth District and lumber in the Twelfth District.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: National Summary > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: On balance, year-over-year price growth remained moderate this cycle. According to our most recent surveys, service sector firms reported virtually no change in price growth while manufacturers saw a slight increase in prices received. Firms in both sectors continued to cite tariffs adding to their input costs, some of which have yet to be passed along to customers. A couple of firms said they expected to raise prices once they worked through their pre-tariff inventory.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Prices rose modestly as in the prior reporting period. Higher import duties led to a widespread cost increase for imported supplies, including raw materials, electrical and electronic components, and food. Many suppliers absorbed some of the price increases. However, retailers reported passing a sizable portion onto consumers, mostly in the mid to high-end markets. Several restauranteurs facing high ingredient costs observed a simultaneous drop in customer traffic and a strong resistance to higher menu prices. This led some restaurants to reduce portion sizes or change recipes. Contacts in the insurance industry also highlighted pushback on price increases with customers bundling insurance benefits to reduce the overall cost.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Overall, nonlabor input costs rose at a robust pace in recent weeks, continuing the trend seen in the prior three reporting periods. Tariffs were frequently cited as drivers of these cost increases across industries. Many manufacturers reported tariff-related cost increases on raw materials, imported components, and chemical inputs. Retail contacts noted tariff-driven cost increases on vehicles, beef, coffee, and chocolate. Two contacts noted that foreign producers were factoring in tariffs and cutting prices accordingly to retain market share. Beyond tariffs, banking and professional and business services contacts continued to report elevated costs for technology and insurance, and manufacturers reported rising utilities costs. In general, costs were expected to grow at a strong pace in the coming months.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Prices rose moderately in late August and September and contacts expected a similar pace of growth over the next 12 months. Nonlabor input costs rose moderately, with contacts highlighting higher costs for energy and raw materials like aluminum, copper, and steel. Manufacturing contacts attributed the increases in metals prices to tariffs. In contrast, several contacts in the construction industry noted no change in input prices in recent weeks. Overall, producer and consumer prices rose moderately. One retail industry analyst said that, in general, retailers were trying to hold off passing tariff-related cost increases on to consumers for as long as possible, though several smaller retailers reported already raising prices because of tariffs.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Contacts generally indicated that selling prices rose modestly in recent weeks, maintaining the pace of growth seen since early 2025. Across industries, contacts continued implementing price increases to cover elevated input costs, with several manufacturers and wholesalers introducing surcharges to cover additional costs related to tariffs. However, pricing power was constrained for other contacts who faced declining demand and heightened price sensitivity. In response, many retail contacts noted offering discounts or raising prices only on select items, while some manufacturers said that they held prices steady despite increased costs to try to gain market share.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: However, most contacts expected further tariff impacts in the months ahead. Contacts reported dwindling inventories of pre-tariff goods and an inability to continue absorbing tariff-related costs. The indexes for future prices paid and future prices received for manufacturers were well above their historical averages in September.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Most business contacts reported continued cost pressures from tariffs, insurance, health care, and utilities. Multiple contacts noted that some suppliers were citing tariffs when raising prices, even if their goods were not subject to increased levies. Another contact reported a 15 percent increase in a liability insurance policy from a year earlier in addition to a nearly 10 percent rise in health-care costs.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Prices have increased moderately since our previous report. A technology firm in Memphis has reported maintaining stable prices but has reduced its price guarantee periods to 30 days. An apparel firm in Memphis expects overall price increases of around three percent, with some items such as uniforms rising 5 percent due to input cost increases. Several contacts reported an increase in grocery food prices, especially beef. A professional services firm in St. Louis reported increasing the prices they charge to customers due to tariffs and competitors also raising their prices. Contacts reported that price increases were not solely due to tariffs but also insurance premiums, utilities, and opportunism. A manufacturer reported slightly increasing their prices to customers as suppliers' costs had increased despite having a primarily domestic supply chain.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Prices rose moderately on average, as certain cost pressures increased. Construction costs, energy prices, and wholesale food prices all increased by at least moderate margins, and liability insurance rates rose sharply. Restaurants' profitability declined in response to rising costs, as menu prices were mostly unchanged. Average hotel prices declined modestly in August from a year earlier, and prices for IT services rose moderately over the same period. Manufacturers' output prices increased modestly on average, with contacts noting increases in the prices of copper and certain tools. Smaller manufacturers passed through a larger share of tariff-induced cost increases to customers. Most contacts expected to face at least modest further cost pressures moving forward, and some were concerned about a possible acceleration of prices in 2026.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Consumer-facing businesses across sectors reported an inability to pass through all these increased costs, with many instead increasing discounts to sustain demand. Contacts reported more aggressive discounts from retailers, lower hotel room rates, and increased incentives on autos and newly constructed homes.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia > Prices

retrieved_chunks.body: Prices increased modestly over the reporting period, but input price pressures were greater. One-fifth of District firms increased the prices they charged to customers in September from a month earlier, and a similar share anticipated increasing their prices in the month ahead. More than half of respondents reported increased input prices over the previous month. Contacts noted significant increases in electricity rates and employee health care premiums for the coming year. Several manufacturers reported that they recently increased prices in response to tariffs or planned future increases. Retail fuel prices in District states decreased slightly on balance since the last report. Prices received by farmers increased in August from a year earlier for corn, sugar beets, potatoes, canola, sunflowers, cattle, hogs, and turkeys; prices for soybeans, wheat, pulse crops, hay, chickens, eggs, and milk decreased from a year earlier.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis > Prices

results.question: What was the relationship between federal policy and electric vehicle sales, and how did this affect overall auto sales?
results.expected_answer: Auto sales were boosted in some districts by strong demand for electric vehicles ahead of the expiration of a federal tax credit at the end of September. However, in the Chicago District, light vehicle sales declined overall, especially for EVs following the end of federal tax credits. This shows the federal tax credit created a pre-expiration demand surge followed by a post-expiration decline.
results.system_answer:
Federal policy—in particular, the pending expiration of a federal electric vehicle (EV) tax credit at the end of September—temporarily boosted EV sales. 

As the credit’s expiration approached, consumers rushed to buy EVs, creating a surge in EV sales that:
- Partly offset otherwise weak or declining auto sales in several Districts, and  
- Helped keep overall auto sales from falling more sharply (Philadelphia, Atlanta, Chicago, Boston, and the national summary all noted strong EV demand tied specifically to the ending tax credit).
results.judge_reasoning:
Key facts in the ground truth:
1) A federal EV tax credit expiring at the end of September boosted EV demand ahead of expiration.
2) This boost in some districts supported overall auto sales.
3) In the Chicago District, overall light vehicle sales declined, especially EVs, after the tax credit ended.
4) The net pattern: pre‑expiration demand surge, post‑expiration decline (with Chicago as a clear example).

Comparison:
- The system answer correctly describes the federal EV tax credit expiring at the end of September and a pre‑expiration rush that boosted EV sales.
- It correctly notes that this surge helped offset weak auto sales and kept overall auto sales from falling more sharply, aligning with “auto sales were boosted in some districts by strong demand for EVs.”
- However, it omits the post‑expiration decline, especially in the Chicago District, and does not mention that in Chicago, light vehicle sales declined overall and EV sales were weak after the credit ended.
- It also positively characterizes the impact in Chicago (“helped keep overall auto sales from falling more sharply”) without acknowledging the documented decline there, but this is more an omission of nuance than a direct contradiction, since the question is about the relationship and effects in general, not specifically a detailed Chicago contrast.

Thus, the system answer captures the pre‑expiration surge and its supportive effect on overall auto sales, but misses the key post‑expiration decline element highlighted in the expected answer. No clear factual contradiction is present; the answer is incomplete.

retrieved_chunks.body: Auto dealers reported a slight decrease in auto sales, following a slight increase last period. Contacts highlighted that sales would have fallen by more if not for a rush to buy electric vehicles (EVs) before the expiration of a federal EV tax credit at the end of September.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia > Trade and Services

retrieved_chunks.body: Retail sales declined slightly over the reporting period. Some transportation carriers for major retailers reported these stores had lower same-store sales as compared with year-earlier levels, and that sales growth for the full-year 2025 would be flat. Some retailers were cautiously optimistic about the upcoming holiday sales season, but a few expect holiday sales to be "meh," and noted that tariffs may soon cause prices to rise, resulting in further softening of demand. At restaurants, diners continued to pull back by skipping desserts and/or alcoholic beverages. Automobile dealers experienced a robust surge in new electric vehicle (EV) sales ahead of the expiration of the EV tax credit.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta > Consumer Spending

retrieved_chunks.body: Consumer spending increased modestly over the reporting period. Contacts reported a healthy back-to-school shopping season as well as strong increases in spending on appliances, computers, and landscaping. However, spending on other consumer electronics and building materials declined some. Leisure and hospitality sales were mixed, with softness in some travel-related categories, including airlines and hotels, but increased spending at restaurants in the fast food, fast casual, and family dining segments. New light vehicle sales were brisk, reflecting a combination of strong underlying demand and the end of tax incentives for electric vehicle purchases. Used vehicle sales remained steady, though dealerships located in low-to-moderate income communities reported softer demand.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago > Consumer Spending

retrieved_chunks.body: Retail sales fell during the reporting period. Building material and garden equipment, furniture, and electronic and appliance stores saw lower sales, while health care and food and beverage retailers reported flat to slight increases in activity. Auto dealers reported weak sales and tighter margins due to higher costs. Overall retail inventories remained steady. Outlooks were pessimistic and tariffs appeared to be one of the primary drivers of uncertainty among contacts.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas > Retail Sales

retrieved_chunks.body: Consumer spending declined slightly over the past month. Several contacts noted household consumption was more volatile recently due to heightened price sensitivity. Sales, deals, and markdowns reportedly drove small surges in purchasing activity for certain businesses, especially purchases by lower income households that need to be more selective. Sales of goods, particularly automotive and sporting goods, declined moderately, underscoring the uneven pullback in household spending between goods and services. Contacts at auto dealerships indicated demand continued to shift from SUVs and electric vehicles to family sedans and used vehicles. To manage softer sales, several firms reported they reduced staffing hours and have grown more cautious about passing along higher input costs in the near term, instead focusing on constraining cost growth. The majority of contacts reported they expect sales in 2026 to outperform this year, despite the recent softness in demand and lower expected spending for the remainder of 2025.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City > Consumer Spending

retrieved_chunks.body: Consumer spending declined slightly in recent weeks, and contacts expected demand to be flat in the coming months. Several retail stores reported a drop in unit sales, and a large retailer reported lower in-store and online traffic. Similarly, a food and hospitality contact said that customers were “more value aware," and another large retailer reported that tariff concerns continued to drag down customer sentiment. One tourism contact, who reported a year-over-year decline in activity, said that visits by Canadians fell by 50 percent. Auto dealers generally reported that sales were flat to down, except for used car sales, which one dealership expected to remain strong in the coming months.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland > Consumer Spending

retrieved_chunks.body: Retailers (non-auto) reported a slight decrease in sales over the current period, down from a slight increase in the prior period. One retailer noted that a seasonal slowdown in September is normal following high spending by consumers during the summer months; however, the retailer reported that sales slowed much earlier in August this year and remained flat through September.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia > Trade and Services

retrieved_chunks.body: On balance, contacts reported that demand for manufactured goods declined modestly in recent weeks after changing little during the prior reporting period. Several manufacturers continued to attribute flat or weaker orders to import tariffs and persistent uncertainty about trade policy. Firms selling into industrial and agricultural equipment production reported particularly weak demand, and one contact added that orders from these producers were below their previous expectation by roughly 25 percent. By contrast, some firms selling into the fossil fuel industry and electricity generation reported higher orders related to data center construction and operation. Manufacturers generally expected demand to increase moderately in the coming months.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland > Manufacturing

results.question: What were the multiple factors affecting labor costs, and how did they interact with wage growth?
results.expected_answer: Wages grew at a modest to moderate pace across all districts. However, labor cost pressures intensified due to outsized increases in employer-sponsored health insurance expenses. Additionally, some contacts in the Chicago District reported moderate increases in nonlabor costs including energy and higher prices for raw materials. This meant total compensation costs were rising faster than wage growth alone would suggest.
results.system_answer:
The context points to two main sets of factors affecting labor costs:

1. **Wages and benefits (especially health insurance):**  
   - Wages were generally growing at a *modest to moderate* pace across Districts ([1], [2], [3], [4], [5], [6], [7], [8], [10], [11], [13], [14]).  
   - However, labor cost pressures **intensified** because employer-sponsored **health insurance expenses rose sharply** ([5], [6], [10]).  
   - Some employers implemented cost-of-living adjustments and increased employer contributions to health insurance, directly adding to labor costs ([6], [10]).

2. **Nonwage cost and profitability pressures that constrained wage growth:**  
   - Firms faced higher **nonlabor input costs** (tariffs on raw materials, imported components, and various goods; higher technology, insurance, utilities, construction, energy, and wholesale food costs) ([9], [15]).  
   - These rising nonlabor costs and weak profitability led some employers to **hold wages steady or hire at or near minimum wage** to control overall costs ([3], [11]).  
   - Elevated uncertainty and weaker demand made many firms cautious about hiring and compensation growth ([5], [10], [11], [13], [14]).

**Interaction with wage growth:**  
- Even though nominal wages were rising modestly to moderately, **overall labor costs were pushed up more than wage growth alone would suggest** because of large increases in benefits costs (especially health insurance).  
- At the same time, higher nonlabor costs and thin margins **limited how much employers were willing or able to raise wages**, contributing to easing wage pressures and a preference for cost control (including minimum-wage hiring and restrained hiring plans).
results.judge_reasoning:
Key points in the expected answer:
1) Wages grew at a modest to moderate pace across all districts.
2) Labor cost pressures intensified due to outsized increases in employer-sponsored health insurance expenses.
3) Some contacts in the Chicago District reported moderate increases in nonlabor costs (energy and higher prices for raw materials).
4) As a result, total compensation costs were rising faster than wage growth alone would suggest.

Comparison:
- The system answer correctly states that wages were generally growing at a modest to moderate pace across districts (matches point 1).
- It correctly states that labor cost pressures intensified because employer-sponsored health insurance expenses rose sharply (matches point 2) and makes clear that this pushed overall labor costs up more than wage growth alone (matches point 4).
- It also notes higher nonlabor input costs including energy, raw materials, etc., which is consistent with point 3, albeit more detailed and generalized beyond just Chicago, but not contradictory.
- The system adds that higher nonlabor costs and weak profitability constrained wage growth (firms holding wages steady or hiring at minimum wage). This is extra context not in the ground truth but not in conflict with it.

There are no factual contradictions with the expected answer. All key elements—modest/moderate wage growth, sharp increases in health insurance costs, higher nonlabor costs, and total labor/compensation costs rising faster than wage growth—are present and accurately described, with some additional, consistent detail.

Therefore the answer is fully correct and somewhat more comprehensive than the expected answer, without introducing errors or contradictions.

Several reports highlighted that lower- and middle-income households continued to seek discounts and promotions in the face of rising prices and elevated economic uncertainty. Manufacturing activity varied by District, and most reports noted challenging conditions due to higher tariffs and waning overall demand. Activity in agriculture, energy, and transportation was generally down among reporting Districts. Conditions in the financial services sector and other interest rate-sensitive sectors, such as residential and commercial real estate, were mixed; some reports noted improved business lending in recent weeks due to lower interest rates, while other reports continued to highlight muted activity. The outlook for future economic growth varied by District and sector. Sentiment reportedly improved in a few Districts, with some contacts expecting an uptick in demand over the next 6 to 12 months. However, many others continued to expect elevated uncertainty to weigh down activity. One District report highlighted the downside risk to growth from a prolonged government shutdown.

results.question: How did federal funding changes affect employment in specific sectors?
results.expected_answer: Federal funding changes negatively impacted employment across multiple sectors: In Boston, cuts to federal grant funding contributed to layoffs in education and health-care sectors. In Cleveland, the nonprofit sector was not filling open positions due to federal grant uncertainty. In New York, nonprofits faced challenges from reduced federal benefit programs, with community health-care centers reporting financial strain. Manufacturing employment in Boston was mixed, with one firm shedding workers to offset tariff-related cost increases.
results.system_answer:
Cuts to federal grant funding led to job losses in specific sectors, particularly:

- **Education and health care:** In the Boston District, reductions in federal grant funding directly contributed to layoffs in these sectors [2].
results.judge_reasoning:
Key facts in the expected answer:
1) In Boston, cuts to federal grant funding contributed to layoffs in education and health-care sectors.
2) In Cleveland, the nonprofit sector was not filling open positions due to federal grant uncertainty.
3) In New York, nonprofits faced challenges from reduced federal benefit programs, with community health-care centers reporting financial strain.
4) Manufacturing employment in Boston was mixed; one firm shed workers to offset tariff-related cost increases.

The system answer includes only point (1): it correctly states that in the Boston District, reductions in federal grant funding led to layoffs in education and health care. It does not mention Cleveland nonprofits, New York nonprofits and community health centers, or the mixed manufacturing employment situation in Boston (including tariff-related layoffs). There are no contradictions with the ground truth, but the answer is incomplete relative to the full question about "specific sectors" across districts.

Thus, the answer is accurate for what it covers but misses several key elements, so it is partially correct, not fully correct.

retrieved_chunks.body: In a semiannual survey of nonprofits, a growing share of respondents indicated that funding for their respective organizations decreased over the past six months. One revealed that their organization had to dip into its reserve fund to cover operating expenses for the first time in more than ten years. Another respondent said that the nonprofit sector was not filling open positions because of uncertainty around federal grants. Respondents who assist jobseekers observed that their clients were more likely than before to receive offers for part-time positions with little or no benefits and that formerly incarcerated jobseekers were having a harder time securing employment.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland > Community Conditions

retrieved_chunks.body: Employment was flat overall, as both hiring and layoffs increased modestly. Manufacturing employment was unchanged on balance, as some firms added workers to meet demand, some kept head counts steady because of uncertainty, and one shed workers to offset tariff-related cost increases. Cuts to federal grant funding contributed to layoffs in the education and health-care sectors. Employment in IT services increased modestly, with hiring in sales and technical positions. Retail and tourism employment was unchanged, as contacts noted modest improvements in worker availability but worried about next summer's labor supply given expected reductions in seasonal visas. Contacts in Maine and Vermont said labor market slack in those states increased, even though certain hiring challenges persisted. Wages rose at a modest pace on average, and some contacts described wage pressures as more muted compared with a year earlier. Manufacturing wages were mixed, but up modestly on average. Salaries at IT firms were unchanged, with moderate annual increases expected at the turn of the year. With isolated exceptions, hiring plans remained limited, owing to rising cost pressures and elevated uncertainty. No major layoffs were expected in the near term, but the longer-term outlook was less secure.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston > Labor Markets

retrieved_chunks.body: Conditions in community support organizations and small businesses weakened moderately. Demand for assistance rose, particularly for food, other basic household necessities, and health care. At the same time, funding and grant cuts limited their ability to provide assistance. Small business owners reported lower demand and strained finances, as they drew down savings and reduced investment. Contacts attributed some of the decline in demand to changes in customers' behavior in response to immigration policy. Reports indicated more business closures and cuts to operating hours as well as some increases in loan delinquencies.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Community Conditions

retrieved_chunks.body: Employment levels were little changed on net over the reporting period. Most employers hired only to replace workers, holding head counts steady. Several contacts in manufacturing and health care noted reductions in staff levels through attrition, layoffs, and early retirements. In some cases, employment reductions were coupled with investment in artificial intelligence (AI), particularly for positions and tasks usually reserved for less experienced employees. In contrast, employers in financial services and insurance continued to hire. The number of applicants for each open position increased, and employers generally found it easier to hire. However, a few contacts in construction and manufacturing noted more difficulty finding workers for their entry-level positions, and they attributed that to reduced immigration. Turnover continued to slow across industries, and some contacts highlighted efforts to prioritize the retention of experienced employees.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Labor Markets

retrieved_chunks.body: On balance, employment remained steady during the reporting period. retrieved_chunks.body: Employment levels in the District were generally flat over the reporting period. Turnover was low, with many describing the level as the lowest in their firm's history, and applicants for open positions were plentiful except for very specific, mostly technical, roles. Recently, however, head count reductions were cited more frequently, and some firms expect further cuts based on early Generative Al implementation results, particularly if demand slows further. Impacts from changes to immigration policy and enforcement were more material than previously reported but were concentrated in certain geographies like south Georgia and sectors such as agriculture and hospitality. Uncertainty around both labor supply and consumer demand continued to weigh on firms' hiring plans.

Employers that reported hiring generally noted improved labor availability, and some favored hiring temporary and part-time workers over offering full-time employment opportunities. Nevertheless, labor supply in the hospitality, agriculture, construction, and manufacturing sectors was reportedly strained in several Districts due to recent changes to immigration policies. In planning for 2026, many nonprofit organizations anticipated the need to find new funding streams and adapt to smaller budgets. Several contacts concurred that hiring had decelerated but also noted that terminations were infrequent.

retrieved_chunks.body: Overall, contact reports suggested a slight increase in employment levels in recent weeks. results.question: What specific factors contributed to economic uncertainty across different districts?
results.expected_answer: Multiple factors contributed to uncertainty: Tariff policy changes made planning difficult for manufacturers (noted in Chicago and across districts). Federal grant uncertainty affected nonprofits (Cleveland, New York, Boston). Policy uncertainty was a top business concern (Dallas). Immigration policy changes created labor supply concerns (St. Louis, Boston). The potential for government shutdown was highlighted as a downside risk. Kansas City noted that despite current decline, 2026 expectations remained optimistic.
results.system_answer:
Several distinct factors contributed to economic uncertainty across different districts:

1. **Tariffs and Trade-Policy Uncertainty**
   - Higher tariffs and “waning overall demand” weighed on manufacturing activity nationally [1], with specific mentions in:
     - Cleveland: Manufacturers cited tariffs and trade-policy uncertainty as driving modest demand declines [3].
     - Philadelphia: Firms reported higher cost pressures from tariffs and expected to raise prices [6].
     - Richmond: Manufacturers cited tariffs as a source of increased price growth [12].

2. **Domestic Policy / Government Risks**
   - Nationally, one District highlighted “downside risk to growth from a prolonged government shutdown” [1].
   - Philadelphia contacts across industries also warned about “additional downside risks of a prolonged government shutdown” [6].
   - Dallas contacts cited “domestic policy uncertainty” as a primary concern going forward [7].

3. **Inflation and Cost Pressures**
   - Nationally, rising prices were noted, with lower- and middle-income households seeking discounts amid “elevated economic uncertainty” [1].
   - New York reported strongly rising input prices and elevated overall price increases [11].
   - Dallas contacts cited inflation as a key concern [7].
   - Labor cost pressures intensified due to higher employer health insurance expenses [13].
   - Boston and other districts noted tariff-related and other cost pressures on prices [8], [15].

4. **Weak or Shifting Demand**
   - National summary noted waning overall demand in manufacturing [1] and softening activity in agriculture, energy, and transportation [1].
   - Dallas: Outlooks worsened with “weakening demand” [7].
   - Kansas City: Sectoral shifts driven by technology, policy shocks, and changing consumer preferences led to mixed and uncertain conditions [5].
   - Richmond: Customer uncertainty and price sensitivity led manufacturers to adjust product offerings [12].

5. **Income and Household Security Concerns**
   - Boston: Community contacts reported greater precarity among low- and moderate-income households (increased food pantry use, difficulties paying bills) and saw risks from planned cuts to SNAP and Medicaid and tariff-linked price increases [2].
   - Boston non-business contacts expressed growing concerns about lower-income households’ economic security [8].

6. **Agricultural Sector Uncertainty**
   - Chicago agriculture: Elevated uncertainty unsettled operators; soybean prices were lower due in part to lack of exports to China; concerns about higher future input costs (rising fertilizer prices) and unclear economic outlook dampened capital investment [14].
   - Minneapolis: Agricultural contacts were concerned about China’s elimination of soybean purchases [9].

7. **Labor Market and Technology-Related Uncertainty**
   - National labor summary: Employers cited “elevated economic uncertainty” and, in some cases, increased investment in AI as reasons for layoffs and reduced head counts [13].

8. **International Factors**
   - Nationally: Demand for leisure and hospitality from international travelers fell further [1], adding to uncertainty in those service sectors.

These factors, varying in prominence by district, collectively contributed to elevated uncertainty about current conditions and future growth.
results.judge_reasoning:
Key expected factors:
1) Tariff policy changes made planning difficult for manufacturers (Chicago and across districts).
2) Federal grant uncertainty affected nonprofits (Cleveland, New York, Boston).
3) Policy uncertainty as a top business concern (Dallas).
4) Immigration policy changes creating labor supply concerns (St. Louis, Boston).
5) Potential for government shutdown as a downside risk.
6) Kansas City: despite current decline, 2026 expectations remained optimistic.

Check system answer:
- It does discuss tariffs/trade-policy uncertainty, but locates them mainly in Cleveland, Philadelphia, Richmond, not Chicago. Still, tariffs as a factor are captured, albeit with different districts.
- It includes domestic policy/government risks and explicitly mentions “downside risk to growth from a prolonged government shutdown” and firms warning about that. This matches the shutdown factor.
- It correctly notes Dallas contacts citing “domestic policy uncertainty” as a primary concern—this aligns with policy uncertainty in Dallas.
- It does not mention federal grant uncertainty affecting nonprofits in Cleveland, New York, or Boston.
- It does not mention immigration policy changes or related labor supply concerns in St. Louis or Boston.
- It adds many other sources of uncertainty (inflation, demand weakness, agricultural uncertainty, labor/AI, international tourism) that are not in the expected answer, but they are not contradictions; they’re extra context.
- Kansas City is mentioned, but in a different way: sectoral shifts and mixed conditions; it does not include the point that expectations for 2026 remained optimistic despite current decline.
- There are no direct contradictions with the ground truth items; the system answer is broader and somewhat misaligned on which districts emphasized tariffs, but that isn’t a direct contradiction of the expected facts.

Overall, the answer captures some key factors (tariffs/trade uncertainty, policy uncertainty in Dallas, government-shutdown risk) but omits others (federal grant uncertainty, immigration policy effects, optimistic 2026 expectations). The present facts appear plausible and not contradictory, but the coverage of the specific factors requested is incomplete.

Therefore the best label is PARTIALLY_CORRECT.

The pace of price increases remained elevated but was little changed, with selling prices rising moderately and input prices rising strongly. Manufacturing activity was little changed after a summer uptick. Consumer spending increased modestly, in part due to the resilience of mid- to upper-income households. Housing markets remained solid. Overall loan demand declined. Businesses did not expect much of an increase in activity in the months ahead.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Summary of Economic Activity

retrieved_chunks.body: The Fifth District economy continued to grow modestly this cycle. Consumer spending at retail and restaurants grew modestly while reports on travel spending were mixed. Consumers were looking for value and comparative price shopping. Manufacturing activity declined slightly amid customer uncertainty and price sensitivity leading some to adjust product offerings to reduce prices. Additionally, ports volumes increased slightly, reflecting early retail ordering for holiday inventories. Activity in the remaining sectors was generally flat. Employment was unchanged, on balance, with firms both growing and cutting labor based on demand. Wage growth remained moderate. Price growth picked up somewhat in manufacturing, with firms citing tariffs, but overall year-over-year price growth remained within a moderate range.

retrieved_chunks.body: Employment levels were largely stable in recent weeks, and demand for labor was generally muted across Districts and sectors. In most Districts, more employers reported lowering head counts through layoffs and attrition, with contacts citing weaker demand, elevated economic uncertainty, and, in some cases, increased investment in artificial intelligence technologies. Employers that reported hiring generally noted improved labor availability, and some favored hiring temporary and part-time workers over offering full-time employment opportunities. Nevertheless, labor supply in the hospitality, agriculture, construction, and manufacturing sectors was reportedly strained in several Districts due to recent changes to immigration policies. Wages grew across all reporting Districts, generally at a modest to moderate pace, and labor cost pressures intensified in recent weeks due to outsized increases in employer-sponsored health insurance expenses.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: National Summary > Labor Markets

retrieved_chunks.body: Net farm income prospects for the District were unchanged over the reporting period, though elevated uncertainty continued to unsettle agricultural operators. Corn and soybean fields were in good shape across most of the District. Dry conditions assisted harvest but hurt yields in some places; in addition, crop disease trimmed yields a bit. Fruit and vegetable production was subpar for most products. Soybean prices were lower, in part due to the absence of new-crop exports to China. Corn prices were down despite strong export volumes. Cattle and hog prices increased to record territory, while milk and egg prices declined. Concerns about higher input costs for 2026 intensified due to rising fertilizer prices. Farm operations, particularly crop producers, have already cut costs, with a contact saying, "there is limited flexibility left to further reduce expenses." Contacts noted that lack of clarity on the economic outlook was putting a damper on capital investment, such as equipment purchases and repairs.
retrieved_chunks.header_path: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago > Agriculture

retrieved_chunks.body: Economic activity expanded slightly, with modest growth in consumer spending. Employment was flat, as both hiring and layoffs increased modestly. The outlook was neutral to cautiously optimistic, but contacts saw mostly downside risks.

results.question: What supply chain disruptions affected manufacturing, and how did they impact production?
results.expected_answer: Supply chain challenges varied across districts. In San Francisco, manufacturers noted higher costs for utilities and imported semiconductor chips. In Chicago, manufacturing demand declined modestly with fabricated metals demand unchanged on balance as higher sales to some sectors were offset by lower sales to construction and automotive industries. Tariff-induced input cost increases affected manufacturing across many districts, with firms reporting difficulty planning due to changing tariff policies. Labor shortages due to immigration policy changes also constrained production in manufacturing, construction, and agriculture sectors.
results.system_answer: I cannot find information about this in the provided context.
results.judge_reasoning: The ground truth clearly contains a detailed answer about supply chain disruptions (higher utility and semiconductor chip costs, tariff-induced input cost increases, planning difficulties due to changing tariffs, and labor shortages linked to immigration policy changes). The system answer says it "cannot find information about this in the provided context," which is an explicit abstention rather than an incorrect factual claim. Since the model declined to answer despite a correct answer existing in the ground truth, this fits the 'abstained' category per the instructions.

results.question: What service-related costs contributed to input cost increases, and how did this affect different sectors?
results.expected_answer: Several service-related costs drove input cost increases: insurance, health care, and technology solutions all saw higher costs. In New York, rising business costs including insurance added to financial pressures for community service providers. Employer-sponsored health insurance expenses saw outsized increases, intensifying labor cost pressures across districts. These service cost increases occurred alongside tariff-driven goods cost increases.
results.system_answer:
The service-related costs that contributed to input cost increases were primarily:

- Insurance (including liability and business insurance)  
- Health care / employee health care premiums  
- Technology and IT/technology solutions  
- Utilities (noted alongside other nonlabor inputs, often affecting services as well as goods)

Effects on different sectors included:

- **Service-sector firms (banking, professional & business services, other services):**  
  Reported elevated costs for technology and insurance, with some noting health-care and business insurance premiums rising faster than revenues. These higher service costs squeezed margins and contributed to expectations of future selling price increases.

- **Restaurants and hospitality:**  
  Faced rising liability insurance and other operating costs, but often kept menu and room prices mostly unchanged due to customer resistance, leading to reduced profitability. Some restaurants responded by shrinking portions or altering recipes.

- **General business contacts across districts:**  
  Many reported cost pressures from insurance, health care, and utilities, with some firms unable to fully pass these costs through, instead using discounts or keeping prices steady to maintain demand.
results.judge_reasoning:
Key elements in the expected answer:
1) Service-related costs that drove input cost increases: insurance, health care, technology solutions.
2) Specific sectoral effect in New York: rising business costs including insurance added to financial pressures for community service providers.
3) Employer-sponsored health insurance saw outsized increases, intensifying labor cost pressures across districts.
4) These service cost increases occurred alongside tariff-driven goods cost increases.

Comparison with system answer:
- The system correctly identifies the core service-related costs: insurance, health care/employee health care premiums, and technology/IT solutions. This matches items (1) from the ground truth.
- It adds “utilities” as a cost pressure. The ground truth doesn’t mention utilities; this is an addition but not a direct contradiction.
- On sectoral effects, the system describes impacts on service-sector firms, restaurants/hospitality, and general business contacts. However, it does not mention the specific New York context or community service providers’ financial pressures, which is a key detail in the expected answer (point 2).
- It also does not mention that employer-sponsored health insurance expenses saw “outsized” increases across districts, nor does it clearly frame health insurance as a particularly strong/intensifying labor cost pressure across districts (point 3). It only generally notes that premiums were rising faster than revenues.
- It omits entirely the note that these service cost increases occurred alongside tariff-driven goods cost increases (point 4).

There are no clear factual contradictions; the answer is broadly consistent with the expected one but misses several specific key points (New York/community service providers, outsized increases across districts, and the linkage to tariff-driven goods costs). Therefore, it is accurate but incomplete, which fits PARTIALLY_CORRECT rather than fully CORRECT.

Some firms facing tariff-induced cost pressures kept their selling prices largely unchanged to preserve market share and in response to pushback from price-sensitive clients. Manufacturers' output prices increased modestly on average, with contacts noting increases in the prices of copper and certain tools. Most contacts expected to face at least modest further cost pressures moving forward, and some were concerned about a possible acceleration of prices in 2026.

Several restauranteurs facing high ingredient costs observed a simultaneous drop in customer traffic and a strong resistance to higher menu prices. This led some restaurants to reduce portion sizes or change recipes. Contacts in the insurance industry also highlighted pushback on price increases with customers bundling insurance benefits to reduce the overall cost.

results.question: Which retail categories saw gains versus declines, and how does this reflect consumer behavior patterns?
results.expected_answer: In Chicago, leisure and hospitality sales were mixed. Categories seeing gains included restaurants in the fast food, fast casual, and family dining segments, as well as new light vehicle sales which were brisk due to strong underlying demand and the end of tax incentives for electric vehicle purchases. Categories seeing softness included travel-related categories such as airlines and hotels. Used vehicle sales remained steady though dealerships in low-to-moderate income communities reported softer demand. This pattern reflects consumers seeking value in dining while cutting back on travel.
results.system_answer:
Gains vs. declines by category, and what they suggest about behavior:

**Categories with gains:**
- **Appliances, computers, landscaping products** (Chicago [1]) – consumers still spending on big-ticket/home-related items, possibly prioritizing productivity and home improvement.
- **Fast food, fast casual, and family dining restaurants** (Chicago [1]); **quick service and luxury restaurants** (Richmond [3]; San Francisco [12]) – consumers are eating out but either trading down to cheaper formats or selectively spending on higher-end experiences.
- **New light vehicles, especially EVs before tax credit expiration** (Chicago [1]; Atlanta [6]; Boston [15]) – time-sensitive, incentive-driven buying; people pull forward purchases to capture tax credits.
- **Luxury goods and athletic footwear** (San Francisco [2]) – higher-income or brand-focused consumers remain willing to spend.
- **Higher‑end/small luxury retailers** (Richmond [3]; Boston [15]) – resilience at the upper end of the market.
- **Apparel, cosmetics, and fragrances** (New York [9]) – discretionary but still solid among mid‑ to upper‑income shoppers.
- **Health‑related food services and some entertainment venues** (San Francisco [12]) – selective spending on perceived wellness and experiences.
- **Health care and food & beverage retailers (modest/flat to slight increases)** (Dallas [5]) – essentials are being maintained.

**Categories with declines:**
- **Other consumer electronics and building materials** (Chicago [1]); **building material and garden equipment, furniture, electronics/appliance stores** (Dallas [5]) – pullback on more discretionary or deferrable goods and home-related big-ticket items.
- **Many consumer goods including food products, beverages, clothing, pet supplies** (San Francisco [2]) – broad softening in everyday retail goods, especially at lower price points.
- **More affordable/lower‑priced goods** (San Francisco [2]) – weaker demand than for luxury, indicating stress on lower- and middle‑income consumers.
- **Casual sit‑down restaurants and full‑service restaurants** (Richmond [3]; San Francisco [12]) – consumers trimming mid‑tier dining; either trading down to quick service or only splurging on select luxury experiences.
- **Travel, hospitality, and tourism in many areas** (Chicago [1]; Minneapolis [7]; Cleveland [10]; St. Louis [11]; San Francisco [12]; parts of Richmond and Boston [3][15]) – reduced or more cautious vacation and business travel, especially among middle-income consumers.
- **Autos in many districts, especially SUVs and EVs post‑incentive**; shift toward **family sedans and used vehicles** (Kansas City [8]; Cleveland [10]; Dallas [5]) – buyers trading down and focusing on value/affordability.
- **General retail (non‑auto) sales and mall traffic** (Philadelphia [4]; Atlanta [6]; Cleveland [10]; Minneapolis [7]; Dallas [5]; Kansas City [8]) – broad softness in discretionary store spending.

**Behavior patterns reflected:**
- **Heightened price sensitivity and “value shopping”:** Multiple districts note consumers looking for deals, promotions, and ways to stretch dollars (Richmond [3][14]; Minneapolis [7]; Kansas City [8]; Cleveland [10]).
- **Bifurcation by income:** Luxury goods, luxury hotels, and higher‑end retailers are doing relatively well, while **budget and mid‑market segments struggle**, indicating that higher‑income consumers remain resilient while middle‑ and lower‑income consumers cut back (San Francisco [2]; Richmond [3]; Boston [15]; St. Louis [11]).
- **Trading down, not stopping entirely:** Shifts from full‑service/casual dining to quick service, from SUVs/EVs to sedans/used cars, and from extras (desserts, alcohol) to core meals (Atlanta [6]; Kansas City [8]) show consumers still consuming but at lower price points.
- **Incentive‑driven and timing‑sensitive purchases:** Strong EV sales before tax credit expirations and early holiday ordering/port volumes (Chicago [1]; Atlanta [6]; Boston [15]; Richmond [14]) indicate consumers and firms reacting to policy/tariff changes.
- **Preference for select experiences and home focus:** Continued spending on certain entertainment venues, some restaurants, and home‑related items (appliances, landscaping, replacement windows) shows consumers prioritizing specific experiences and home improvement over broad discretionary retail (Chicago [1]; Richmond [3]; San Francisco [12]).
results.judge_reasoning:
Key facts in the expected answer:
1) Retail categories with gains in Chicago: 
   - Restaurants in fast food, fast casual, and family dining segments
   - New light vehicle sales were brisk, especially around the end of EV tax incentives
2) Categories with softness/declines in Chicago:
   - Travel-related categories such as airlines and hotels
   - Used vehicle sales overall steady but softer demand in low‑to‑moderate income communities
3) Behavioral interpretation:
   - Consumers are seeking value in dining
   - Consumers are cutting back on travel

Comparison with the system answer:
- Gains:
  • The system explicitly mentions **fast food, fast casual, and family dining restaurants** in Chicago as categories with gains – this matches the expected answer.
  • It also notes **new light vehicles, especially EVs before tax credit expiration**, as a gain category and correctly ties this to tax credit timing – also aligned with the expected answer.
- Declines/softness:
  • The system lists **travel, hospitality, and tourism** as a declining category and explicitly includes Chicago in the list of districts. That correctly reflects softness in travel-related categories (airlines and hotels) from the expected answer, though it’s embedded in a broader multi‑district discussion.
  • For autos, the system says **autos in many districts, especially SUVs and EVs post‑incentive; shift toward family sedans and used vehicles**. This does not contradict the ground truth (which says used vehicle sales remained steady overall but were softer in low‑ to moderate‑income communities). The system’s statement is broader and multi‑district, but not in direct conflict with Chicago’s described pattern.
- Behavioral patterns:
  • The system’s behavior interpretation emphasizes **heightened price sensitivity and value shopping**, **trading down (e.g., from full‑service to quick service restaurants)**, and **incentive‑driven purchases (EVs before tax credit expiration)**. These themes are consistent with “consumers seeking value in dining” and “pulling forward vehicle purchases due to incentives.”
  • It also notes **reduced or more cautious travel**, which is consistent with “cutting back on travel.”

The system answer adds a lot of extra, cross‑district detail beyond what the expected answer requires, but that is allowed. Crucially, it includes all key Chicago facts (restaurant gains, new light vehicle gains related to incentives, softness in travel) and a behavior interpretation that is consistent with seeking value in dining and cutting back on travel. It does not contradict any of the expected points; it simply goes further and more broadly. Therefore the answer should be judged CORRECT, not just partial.
